description: Most recent 500 Q&A pairs + quarterly 10-Q summary

results.question: Yes, good morning. This question is for Jamie. Jamie, you were on the media today talking about potential economic turbulence, but Jeremy also mentioned that banking should be -- the banking system should be a source of strength in this turbulence. The equity market always seems to think about the banks as weaker players, given how they trade the stocks more on sentiment and fear rather than the math of the ability of the banks to absorb provisions going forward if we do fall into a slower economic downturn. So, I guess, just the question here is, can you double-click on how you think this is going to impact the economy going forward? And maybe double-click on Jeremy's statement that banking -- the banking system should be a source of strength?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Everyone trades stocks in a different way. So, sentiment -- but banks are a cork in the ocean when it comes to the economy. If the economy gets worse, credit loss will go up, volumes can change, yield curve can change, and we're not predicting all of that. What I would say is our excellent economist, Michael Feroli, I called him this morning, specifically to ask him with -- how they're looking at their forecast today. They think it's about 50-50 for recession, so I'll just refer to that. Obviously, if there's a recession, credit loss will go up, and other factors will change, too.

And I think the one thing I'll add to what Jeremy said is, and I don't usually pay that much attention to anecdotes, but this time I am, and I think you're going to see a lot of companies, you guys -- not you, but the analyst community has already reduced its earnings estimates for the S&P by 5%. So, it's now up 5% as opposed to up 10%. My guess is that'll be 0% and negative 5% probably the next month.

And then, you're going to hear a thousand companies report and they're going to tell you what their guidance is. My guess is, a lot will remove it. They're going to tell you what they think it might do to their customers, their base, their earnings, their cost, their tariffs. It's different for every company, but I assume you see that.

And anecdotally, a lot of people are not doing things because of this. They're going to wait and see. And that's M&A, M&A with middle market companies, that's people's hiring plans and stuff like that. So, people have to adjust this new environment. And I think you will see what it is.

I just also want to point out just so you can round it up, this is to make you feel comfortable, not uncomfortable. When COVID hit, unemployment went from like 4% to 15% in a couple of months, and we had to add to reserves in a two-month period $15 billion. And then, to show you how stupid CECL is, in the three month -- three-quarter period, we took down the $15 billion. So that just sizes up a bad recession. If it's a mild recession, it will be less than that. If it's a really bad recession, it will be more than that. Either way, we can handle it and serve our clients. Earnings won't be great and the stock will go down, which I look at as an opportunity to buy back more stock.
results.generated_answer:
Thank you for the question. It's important to acknowledge both the potential challenges and the strengths of the banking system as we navigate through economic turbulence. As Jeremy mentioned, the banking system should indeed be a source of strength. This is because banks today are far more resilient than they were before the 2008 financial crisis. We've built up substantial capital and liquidity buffers, and our risk management practices have evolved significantly to better withstand economic shocks. 

The market often reacts to sentiment and fear, but if you look at the fundamentals, you'll see that banks are in a strong position to support the economy. We are prepared to manage through a downturn by continuing to provide credit and liquidity to our clients, which is crucial for maintaining economic stability. 

The potential economic turbulence we're talking about could stem from a variety of factors, including geopolitical tensions, inflationary pressures, and interest rate movements. However, the diversified nature of our business allows us to adapt and respond to these challenges. We have experience navigating through uncertain times and are committed to meeting the needs of our clients while maintaining our financial strength.

The key is to remain cautious and prepared. We have the capital and the robust risk management frameworks necessary to handle a range of economic scenarios. This allows us to continue playing a critical role in supporting the economy, even as we face headwinds. So while the market may react to immediate concerns, our focus is on the long-term stability and health of the banking system and our ability to continue serving our clients effectively.

results.question: Okay, got it. And then, just on capital, how does this type of macro uncertainty impact your thinking around conserving capital as opposed to deploying it through your investment agenda and buybacks as the stock gets cheaper? Just are you still looking to arrest the increase or does this kind of change it?
results.ground_truth_answer: The investment that we do in banks, branches, technology, AI is going to continue regardless of the environment. And then, we have, depending what happens to Basel III and CCAR and G-SIFI and all that, $30 billion to $60 billion of excess capital. And in the Chairman's letter, I wrote about what we think of that, but based upon the environment, the turbulence issues, I like having excess capital. We are prepared for any environment and that's so we can serve clients. That's not for any other reason. So -- but we have plenty of capital and plenty of liquidity to get through whatever the stormy seas are.
results.generated_answer:
Certainly, let me address that. When it comes to capital, our primary focus has always been on maintaining a robust and resilient balance sheet that can withstand a variety of economic scenarios. In times of macroeconomic uncertainty, our approach is to be prudent and deliberate in how we allocate capital. This includes a careful evaluation of our investment opportunities, ensuring that any deployment of capital is aligned with our long-term strategic goals and provides a satisfactory risk-adjusted return.

Regarding buybacks, we have always taken a disciplined approach. While we recognize that our stock may look attractive when it's cheaper, we balance buybacks with other considerations such as potential future opportunities and maintaining a strong capital cushion. Buybacks are a tool we use when the time is right, and the capital isn't better deployed elsewhere to serve our clients or invest in our business.

In terms of our investment agenda, we remain committed to strategic investments that drive growth and enhance our competitive position, especially in areas like technology and expanding our footprint. However, we also recognize the need to be agile and adjust our plans based on the evolving economic landscape. 

In summary, while we continue to focus on opportunities for growth and value creation, we do so with an eye on maintaining flexibility and strength in our capital position, particularly in uncertain macro environments. This allows us not only to weather any potential storms but also to seize opportunities as they arise.

results.question: Hi, good morning, and thanks for taking my questions. Wanted to start off with one on the proposed SLR changes and just the impact of rate volatility. The treasury is committed to providing relief to the banks under the SLR just to help mitigate some of the volatility in the 10-year. But given the geopolitical concerns, weakening global demand for treasuries, how does it inform your appetite just for purchasing US treasuries if those reforms are implemented? And just how you're managing rate risk maybe more holistically across the firm just in light of some of the recent volatility?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Yeah. So, SLR alone isn't going to change that much for us. It may change for other people. We really need reform across SLR, G-SIFI, CCAR, Basel III and LCR, all of which has deep flaws in them, to make a material change. And remember, it's not relief to the banks. It's relief to the markets. JPMorgan will be fine with/without an SLR change.

The reason to change some of these things is so banks -- the big market makers could intermediate more in the markets. If they don't -- if they do, spreads will come in, there'll be more active traders. If they don't, the Fed will have to intermediate, which I think is just a bad policy idea, but every time there's a kerfuffle in the markets, the Fed has to come in and intermediate. So, they should make these changes.

The reason why is when you have very -- lot of volatile markets and very widespread and low liquidity in treasuries, it affects all other capital markets. That's the reason to do it, not as a favor to the banks themselves. And anyway -- and we don't take more interest rate exposure to this in any way, shape or form. It's not like we're going to change our position. We intermediate the markets, help clients do what they have to do. And if the banks could take bigger positions, they would have just larger dealer positions and take no -- basically take not much more interest rate exposure. I should say that our folks did a fabulous job trading this quarter.
results.generated_answer:
Good morning, and thank you for the question. The proposed changes to the Supplementary Leverage Ratio (SLR) are certainly relevant in the context of managing our balance sheet and interest rate exposure. If the SLR reforms are implemented, they could provide some relief and flexibility in managing our capital and liquidity. 

When it comes to purchasing U.S. treasuries, our approach is guided by a mix of economic conditions, market dynamics, and regulatory requirements. We always evaluate the risk-reward profile of holding treasuries in our portfolio. With the recent rate volatility, we're mindful of potential impacts on our balance sheet, particularly given the geopolitical uncertainties and shifts in global demand for treasuries.

In terms of managing rate risk holistically, we have a robust framework in place to assess and respond to interest rate movements. Our balance sheet is well-positioned with a significant amount of cash and high-quality liquid assets, which gives us the flexibility to adapt to changes in the rate environment. We continually monitor the yield curve and adjust our strategies accordingly, seeking to optimize our interest rate exposure while ensuring we maintain a strong liquidity position.

Overall, we're committed to navigating these challenges prudently, leveraging our strong capital and liquidity positions to continue serving our clients effectively.

results.question: Very good. Thank you. And then, as a follow-up, you both just talked about the potential changes to the different regulatory outcomes for you and your peers, whether it's SLR or the G-SIB buffer, et cetera. Can you opine for us your views? Are you more confident with the new administration, the new personnel, whether it's Treasury Secretary Bessent or others, the nominees for different regulatory heads, that there will be a better chance of real regulatory reform they see it the way you guys do versus the prior administration?
results.ground_truth_answer: Yeah. I think there's a deep recognition of the flaws in the system. And there should be -- and fortunately, they're going to take a good look at it.
results.generated_answer:
Thank you for the question. Look, when it comes to regulatory reform, it's always a bit of a mixed bag. With a new administration and new personnel at the helm, like Treasury Secretary Yellen and others, there is certainly an opportunity for fresh perspectives. However, it's important to remember that regulatory processes are complex and often influenced by a myriad of factors beyond just the individuals in charge.

I think what we can hope for, and what we certainly advocate for, is a thoughtful examination of the current regulatory framework—one that truly considers the broader economic implications and the health of the financial system as a whole. My hope is that regulators will take into account the lessons from the past, especially from the recent crisis, and look at recalibrating some of the rules that may not make sense in today's environment. This includes looking at things like SLR, G-SIB buffers, and how we address operational risk capital.

It's not about rolling back necessary safeguards—those are important—but about ensuring that regulations are effective and allow banks to serve their critical role in supporting economic growth. We've seen how banks have been a source of strength during the recent crisis, and we want to continue to be able to do that. So, in terms of confidence, I think there's always room for optimism when there's a chance to engage in meaningful dialogue and reform, but we have to wait and see how things unfold. We will continue to make our case and work constructively with regulators to achieve the best outcomes for our clients, shareholders, and the broader economy.

results.question: Thank you. Good morning. I guess just wanted to follow-up on the macro uncertainty. I think when you talk to investors, we've gone from enthusiasm for a pro-business administration to a lot of headwinds. And I think Jamie mentioned you will have companies take down guidance, et cetera, potentially over the coming weeks. I'm just wondering what is it you think we need to see before this uncertainty abates? Are the 90-day pause that we saw with some of the other countries on tariffs, is that enough? Or I'm just wondering when you talk to clients, corporate CEOs, what are they looking for from the administration that would inject confidence to get back anywhere close to where we were maybe 60 or 90 days ago?
results.ground_truth_answer: First of all, some of all the issues that are raised existed before the new administration, like the geopolitical situation, the excess fiscal deficits, poorly done regulations and all of that. Obviously, pro-growth is good, pro-business is good, pro-dereg is good. I think the best thing to do is to allow the Secretary of Treasury and the folks working with him in the administration to finish as quick as possible the agreements that they need to make with -- around tariffs and with our trading partners. And I think there'll be agreements in principle, they're not going to be -- trade agreements themselves would be 5,000 or 10,000 pages long. And that's the best way to go about it right now. That does not mean you won't have some of the effects take place anyway.
results.generated_answer:
Thank you for the question. It's a good one, and it touches on a lot of the current sentiment out there. We are indeed living through a period of heightened macro uncertainty, and it’s important to recognize the complexity of the factors at play.

When I talk to corporate CEOs and clients, the primary concerns are around clarity and stability. The uncertainty around tariffs, trade policies, and geopolitical tensions have significant implications for supply chains, investment decisions, and overall business confidence. A 90-day pause on tariffs is certainly a step in the right direction, but it's more of a temporary relief than a long-term solution. What businesses are really looking for is a clear and consistent policy framework that they can plan around.

Beyond that, there is a need for constructive dialogue between major economies to address trade imbalances and other issues in a way that supports global growth. Businesses thrive on predictability, and policy uncertainty can dampen investment and hiring decisions. So, a clear path forward with regard to trade policies, combined with a broader commitment to fostering a stable business environment, would go a long way toward restoring confidence.

In addition, I think it’s crucial for the administration to focus on the fundamentals that drive economic growth, such as infrastructure investment, workforce development, and innovation. By addressing these areas, we can create a more resilient and competitive economy that can withstand external shocks.

Ultimately, businesses are adaptable, and they will find ways to navigate through challenges. But having a clear roadmap and a supportive policy environment makes that journey much smoother. That’s what we’re hearing from our clients, and it’s something I believe is achievable with thoughtful leadership and collaboration.

results.question: Got it. And I guess, as a follow-up, I think there's a lot of concern also in the treasury markets. We've seen the 10-year move from 3.99% to 4.50% in a matter of week. Just your comfort level in terms of the functioning of the treasury market? Do you see the Fed stepping in, pausing QT, maybe even initiating some treasury purchases? Any color would be great.
results.ground_truth_answer:
Yeah. But again, I mean, we have sticky inflation. We had that before. I personally have told you, I don't think that's going to go away and that relates to that. Obviously, the US dollar still is the reserve currency, and that isn't going to change, though some people may feel slightly differently about it. And the Fed -- we've been consistent. There will be a kerfuffle of the treasury markets because of all the rules and regulations. I've told you that consistently it happened in COVID, it happened before, it happened, that will happen and then when that happens, the Fed will step in. That's what happens. And they're not going to do it now because you don't have all those issues yet. They'll do it when they start to panic a little bit and we don't know if and when that's going to happen and we'll see.

But the notion that the 10-year treasury has to go down is a false notion. If we look at history in prior times, we have huge global deficits back in the '70s, in the '60s, the guns and butter, tariffs, at least our economists think, will be inflationary to 0.5% or something like that. So, we'll have to wait and see and deal with it.
results.generated_answer:
Well, I think it's important to acknowledge that the treasury market is the backbone of the global financial system, and any significant volatility there is a cause for concern. The recent moves in the 10-year yield certainly reflect a lot of uncertainty in the market about the economic outlook and the future path of monetary policy. 

As for the Fed stepping in, they have a range of tools at their disposal, including pausing QT or even reinitiating treasury purchases if they deem it necessary to ensure the smooth functioning of the markets. We saw during the pandemic how quickly and effectively they can act to stabilize the financial system. 

However, it's also crucial for market participants to understand that these tools are not without their consequences. The Fed has to balance the need for market stability with its long-term objectives, including controlling inflation and maintaining employment levels. 

As for our position, JPMorgan is well-prepared to navigate these fluctuations. We manage our balance sheet with a long-term view, and we are well-capitalized to handle periods of volatility. We continue to focus on serving our clients and maintaining our role as a port in the storm during uncertain times.

results.question: Thank you.
results.ground_truth_answer: For most -- mostly we haven't dealt with this stuff before and you're going to see a lot of stuff taking place shortly in the next couple of months and then we'll know.
results.generated_answer:
Thank you. I'm pleased to address your question regarding our current performance and outlook. JPMorgan Chase has demonstrated resilience and robust growth in the first quarter of 2025, with net income rising by 9% year-over-year to $14.6 billion and an EPS of $5.07, reflecting a 14% increase. We've maintained a strong ROE of 18%, and our total net revenue increased by 8% to $45.3 billion, driven by both net interest income and noninterest revenue growth.

Our performance this quarter was bolstered by strategic initiatives, including a significant gain from the First Republic acquisition. Our diversified business model continues to serve us well, with strong contributions from our Consumer & Community Banking, Commercial & Investment Bank, and Asset & Wealth Management segments.

Looking ahead, we remain focused on strategic growth through investments in technology and expanding our client base. While we are navigating a dynamic economic environment, we expect our net interest income for 2025 to be approximately $94.5 billion. We're also committed to managing expenses and maintaining credit quality.

In terms of capital deployment, we're cautiously optimistic. We have a robust capital position with a CET1 capital ratio of 15.4%. Our strategy remains to serve our clients effectively while being prudent with capital allocation, keeping an eye on potential market opportunities and challenges.

Overall, we're confident in our ability to continue delivering strong financial performance and value to our shareholders, while also maintaining our commitment to serving our clients and communities effectively. Thank you.

results.question: Right. And maybe just...
results.ground_truth_answer: It will not happen that way. And we have a lot of options and we want to do change our exposure to interest rate.
results.generated_answer:
Thank you for the question. It's important to recognize the role that banks, including JPMorgan Chase, are playing during these challenging times. We've been focused on supporting our clients and communities through various means, whether it's providing liquidity, participating in government programs, or offering forbearance options to those in need. 

Our approach has always been to think long-term, investing in our people, technology, and infrastructure to ensure we're well-positioned to serve our clients in any economic environment. We are committed to being a part of the solution, working alongside policymakers and other stakeholders to foster stability and growth.

As we navigate through these unprecedented times, we continue to prioritize our core values and strategic initiatives. This includes expanding our footprint, leveraging technology to enhance client experiences, and maintaining a strong capital and liquidity position to withstand any future uncertainties. It's about striking a balance between immediate needs and long-term growth, and we're confident in our ability to manage that effectively. 

So, as we look ahead, we'll remain focused on our strategic priorities, ensuring that we not only weather the current storm but also emerge stronger and more resilient, ready to seize opportunities that lie ahead.

results.question: Right. And maybe just on that point on volumes and deposits, obviously, this kind of volatility tends to drive -- as corporates and investors go to cash, tends to drive higher deposits. Did you see that trend in March and particularly in April? What are the trends like in the deposit side of the equation?
results.ground_truth_answer: I'll just also say that it may not be deposits, it may be treasury bills or various other things. And what you've seen, which is different, is not the risk-off trade in the 10-year. That is fundamentally different this time.
results.generated_answer:
A: Absolutely, we've seen a significant increase in deposits, particularly as corporates and investors have moved more towards cash during this period of volatility. In March and April, we observed a notable influx of deposits, largely driven by a combination of factors including the drawdown of revolvers by corporations, government stimulus payments, and an overall flight to safety given the uncertain economic environment. This trend has been consistent across both our consumer and wholesale banking segments.

For corporates, the initial reaction was to shore up liquidity, which led to revolver drawdowns and increased cash holdings. Many of those same corporates have subsequently issued bonds to term out some of that short-term borrowing, which has also contributed to the deposit growth as the proceeds initially sit on balance sheets.

On the consumer side, the fiscal stimulus measures, including direct deposits from the government, have also played a significant role in the increase in deposits. Customers have been more cautious with their spending, leading to higher savings rates and, consequently, higher deposit balances.

It's important to highlight that this influx of deposits provides us with a strategic advantage in terms of liquidity and capital flexibility, allowing us to continue supporting our clients through lending and other financial services. However, we remain mindful of the fact that, as the economy stabilizes and markets normalize, we might see some of these deposits flow back out, especially as corporates deploy cash for growth initiatives or as consumer spending patterns adjust. We are prepared to manage these dynamics proactively, ensuring that we maintain a strong liquidity position throughout.

results.question: Thanks. Good morning, Jamie. Good morning, Jeremy. Two questions, one for Jamie to kick off. Jamie, you've been through many cycles. And I think we're all interested in understanding how you think this next cycle is likely to progress. And I'm wondering, is there anything that you've seen in the past that looks like this or that you would suggest if any slowdown coming forward, is it more likely to be similar to what kind of prior cycle you've seen?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Again, almost impossible to answer. We look at all the cycles. We prepare for a full range of outcomes. So, not -- I don't personally like predicting what the future is going to hold, but I do -- I pointed out over and over, there's a lot of issues out there. I think some of those issues you are going to see them resolve for better or for worse in the next four months. So, maybe when we're doing this call next quarter, we won't have to be guessing. We actually know what the effect of some of these things was with some predictability and stuff like that.

But it's -- the result in a bank is almost always the same, which is volatile markets, credit losses go up, people get more conservative, investments go down. It looks like a recession. Is it mild or hard? I don't know. But we are -- I've been quite cautious and you can see it in our capital, liquidity, our position, our balance sheet, and so we're prepared. But we do all that so we can serve our clients through thick or thin. We're not guessing about what the future is going to hold. Obviously, if you look at our numbers, we have the margins and capability to get through just about anything.
results.generated_answer:
Thank you for the question. It's always a challenge to directly compare one economic cycle to another, given the unique set of variables at play each time. However, there are certainly elements of past cycles that can offer some insights into what we might expect going forward.

In this particular environment, we're dealing with a number of factors that make it somewhat distinct. We've had significant fiscal and monetary stimulus, supply chain disruptions, and of course, the ongoing impact of the pandemic, which are all playing a role in shaping economic outcomes. If we look back, there are aspects of the early 2000s and post-2008 recovery periods that might offer some parallels, particularly the importance of consumer behavior and government intervention in stabilizing the economy.

However, one thing that stands out today is the potential for higher inflation, which we haven't really seen in recent cycles. This is something that we're keeping a close eye on, and it could influence how central banks respond, potentially leading to a quicker adjustment in interest rates than we've seen in past recoveries.

As always, we're preparing for a range of outcomes. We know there will be ups and downs, and our focus remains on serving our clients and managing risk prudently. While there are uncertainties, the fundamentals of the economy remain strong, and we're well-positioned to navigate whatever comes next.

results.question: Excellent. Okay. No, thank you for that. And then...
results.ground_truth_answer: So, Betsy, this is different, okay? This is different. This is the global economy and please read my Chairman's letter, the most important thing to me is the Western world stays together economically when we get through all this and militarily to keep the world safe and free for democracy. That is the most important thing. I really almost don't care fundamentally about what the economy does in the next two quarters. That isn't that important. We'll get through that. We've had recessions before and all that. It's the ultimate outcome. What's the goal? How can we get there? And it's literally that. I mean, and I -- the China issue is a major issue. I don't know how that's going to turn out. We obviously have to follow the law of the land, but it's a significant change we've never seen in our lives.
results.generated_answer:
Sure, let me try to address that based on our current outlook and performance.

Thank you for the question. First, let me say that we're proud of how JPMorgan Chase has navigated the challenging environment so far. Our robust performance in the first quarter of 2025, with a 9% increase in net income year-over-year, underscores our resilience and ability to adapt to changing market conditions. This is a testament to our diversified business model and disciplined risk management.

Looking at the broader landscape, I think it's important to acknowledge the role that banks, including JPMorgan Chase, have played as a stabilizing force in these turbulent times. As you mentioned, during this crisis, banks have stepped up significantly, not just in supporting clients and employees but also in facilitating government initiatives like the PPP. We've been able to maintain strong capital and liquidity positions while continuing to lend and support the communities we serve.

Now, regarding the future, we remain vigilant. The economic recovery is underway, but it's uneven, and there are still uncertainties, such as potential interest rate movements and regulatory developments. We're prepared for a range of outcomes, and our focus is on staying close to our clients, understanding their needs, and continuing to deliver on our strategic priorities, including disciplined expense management and strategic investments that drive growth.

Overall, I believe we're well-positioned to navigate any headwinds that might come our way and continue to create value for our shareholders while supporting our clients and communities. As always, we'll remain flexible and ready to adapt as the economic landscape evolves. Thank you.

results.question:
Hey, Jamie, you just said on this call, there's a "deep recognition of flaws" by the new regulatory regime. And can you put -- you or Jeremy put some meat on the bones as far as what's been an ideal scenario? You keep the safety and soundness of the system, but you rid as much as red tape and bureaucracy as possible. How much could expenses potentially decline? I assume you'd pass on some of that to customers and you'd keep some of that and the regulators would save money. So, some meat on the bones about the potential concrete savings from deregulation?

But before that, the negative which you highlight in the press release and the Chairman letter about the trade wars, Jamie, you went from trade wars "get over it" to this week say "do something." So just as far as the tariff journey, what were you initially expecting to what happened? And do you really think next earnings call will be through most of the uncertainty? Thanks.
results.ground_truth_answer:
Yeah. No, I don't think we'll necessarily be through all the uncertainty. I think you'll just know a lot more. And my quote was about to "get over it," I wish I hadn't said it. I was specifically referring tariffs relating to protecting national security. National security is paramount. All things should be subordinated to it.

You may need tariffs to help fix some of the problems related to national security. National security is a small part of trade. So -- and it's rare earths, penicillin, medical ingredients, certain types of -- obviously, you've heard about semiconductors. That was my quote about "get over it." I did not change my view about it.

I would like to see the administration negotiate trade deals. I think that'll be good for everybody, and they want to do it, too. Maybe the extent they want to do it, they said they're having conversations with 70 or 80 different people. And so, I do think if the regulators change regulations, it will free up capital and liquidity to finance the system.

And I don't -- I wouldn't expect an expense drawdown that you're going to see, okay? There will be thousands -- hundreds of people maybe, but it's not going to be [passed on] (ph), but it will reduce net-net the cost of liquidity and the cost of loans and the cost of mortgages if it's done right.

I specifically pointed out the mortgage issue in my Chairman's letter this year about if they do some of these reforms, the cost of mortgages come down 70 basis points. If I were them, I'd be focusing that right now.
results.generated_answer:
Certainly. Let's start with the regulatory environment and potential for streamlining. When I talk about recognizing flaws in the regulatory regime, I'm referring to the need for a more balanced approach. We need to maintain the safety and soundness of the financial system while avoiding unnecessary complexity and red tape that doesn't contribute to those goals. By simplifying and recalibrating the rules—especially those that overlap or have unintended consequences—we could see meaningful cost savings. The efficiencies gained would not only benefit banks like ours but could also translate into better pricing and services for customers. It’s hard to quantify exactly, but reducing unnecessary regulatory burdens could potentially save billions across the industry, which we would aim to reinvest in technology and customer service, and yes, some of that would be passed on to shareholders in the form of improved returns.

As for trade wars, my stance has evolved as we've seen the impact unfold. Initially, I suggested we "get over it" because I believed businesses could adapt to some tariffs and trade disruptions in the short term. However, the prolonged nature and the uncertainty surrounding these trade tensions have made their impact more significant than anticipated. It's affecting global supply chains, business investment decisions, and overall economic sentiment. So when I say "do something," I'm emphasizing the need for clear, decisive actions to resolve these trade disputes. It's essential for business confidence and stability. I hope by the next earnings call, we'll have more clarity, but as always, we need to prepare for continued volatility and be ready to manage through it.

results.question: No. And you also mentioned hundreds of billions of dollars of extra lending if you reduce the CET1 ratio, I guess, back down by one-fifth. So...
results.ground_truth_answer:
If you do all -- if you have to fix LCR, G-SIFI, CCAR, SLR, and I think would free up hundreds of billions of dollars for JPMorgan annually of various types of lending to the system. Some would be markets, some would be middle market loans, et cetera. And I pointed out, if you wanted to look at the big numbers, that loans to deposits are now 70% for the banking system writ large. That used to be 100%. And the reason for that isn't -- it's not just capital. It is also LCR. It is also G-SIFIs.

And the question you should ask, because you are very smart, Mike, is could you -- have the same -- and I believe you have a safer system, lend more money, have more liquidity, eliminate bank runs, eliminate what happened to the First Republic of Silicon Valley, and you can accomplish all of that with completely rational and thoughtful regulations. That's what I would like to see them do. I don't know what's going to happen.

You can read our -- I think our [MPRs] (ph) are public and stuff like that. And so, they should do that, just make a better system. We have the best in the world. We've kind of started to cripple it slowly. And if you don't -- I'd say, when you look at these rules and regulations, see Europe. If that's where we want to go, let's just go there.
results.generated_answer:

And I'm not saying it's not going to grow some more, but I just -- I would have a slight reluctance depending on who it was. But you might -- your bankers might come to us with something tomorrow that we just hadn't thought about that is a complete natural fit for us, natural fit being product and people and culture.

In the context of discussing "peak private credit," I'm referring to the rapid growth and expansion of private credit markets over recent years. Private credit has been a crucial alternative source of financing, especially as banks have faced increased regulatory constraints post-2008.

However, the term "peak" suggests that we need to be cautious about the sustainability of this trajectory. results.question:
I'd like to circle back to the return on tangible common equity topic that you guys have discussed. Obviously, you had a very strong number this quarter, 20% when you adjusted for the onetime effect. And you go back to your Investor Day and you pointed out 17% is what the targeted level is.

And if you turn back the clock and go back to 2020, you had the same 17% goal for the ROTCE, but your CET1 ratio back then was guidance -- guidance was 11.5% to 12%. And so the goal is to find opportunities to grow and expand your franchise, which we are doing.

If you look at it, we are doing that with branches and bankers internationally. And when we look at the mid-cap business we're doing in Europe is it's been great. Innovation economy has been great. We're gaining shares in a lot of places, Chase Wealth Management and the Private Bank, the international -- payment systems, we're investing in all those things to grow our franchises, and that's the best way to use your capital. You have all of our major bank competitors are back, rolling and expanding. Then you have the fintech folks, who are quite capable and quite smart, who you don't want to take big chunks of your business. Everything we do is kind of competitive around the world. So the notion is that somehow we're not going to deal with tough competitors, right, which protects JPMorgan Chase, if we don't get complacent, we don't get arrogant, we don't get bureaucratic. And we keep on realizing -- you keep on finding that you got to have to fight for it every day.

And so we're quite cautious to just declare victory, like somehow we're entitled to these returns forever. I also pointed out, if you could compound at 17%, because I had Jeremy do this number one point, if you compounded at 17% for 20 years, you probably would have a good chunk of the GDP of the United States of America -- for 40 years maybe.

results.question:

So I'm just trying to put this in some sort of context that as it relates to Tricolor, who bears the losses? Does end investors in the funds? Is it -- do you put skin in the game and have your own investments? Are you an underwriter? Where are you exposed? But if you look at like COs, CLOs and lending to leveraged entities that are underwritten with leveraged loans, so there's kind of a little bit of double leverage in there.

I would say that, yes, there will be additional risk in that category that we will see when we have a downturn. I expect to be a little bit worse than other people expect it to be because we don't know all the underwriting standards that all of these people did. Jeremy said these are very smart players. So yes, I think you'd be a little bit worse. And hopefully, it will be a fairly normal credit cycle. What always happens is something is worse than a normal credit cycle than a normal downturn. So we'll see. But we think we're quite careful. And obviously, we scour the world looking for things that we should be worried about.

results.question: Jeremy, obviously, you guys are in the residential mortgage lending market, big players granted home lending. There is just excessive stuff put in place after the great financial crisis, which obviously demanded a response but it's excessive. Yes. And I just add the Dana number, they are doing that. They're looking at it holistically, that's great. But Dana number is right.
